meta_description: Bainbridge Island Historical Museum - Preserving the colorful history of Bainbridge Island.
hours_text:
Visit

# Plan a Visit

Whether you’re a resident or a visitor, Bainbridge Island feels like a special place. Come visit — we’re only a ten-minute walk from the ferry.

**Accessibility**  
Public parking nearby. Wheelchair accessible, including parking and drop-off.

**Japanese American Exclusion**  
It is also free to visit the [Bainbridge Island Japanese American Exclusion Memorial (BIJAEM)](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/http://bijaema.org/), open sunrise to sunset. There is often a National Park Service Ranger on site to welcome you during the summer. For more information on the Japanese American Exclusion, visit the [ Bainbridge Island Japanese American Community (BIJAC)](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/https://www.bijac.org/).

**Historic Sites**  
Other popular historic sites on Bainbridge Island include [Bloedel Reserve](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/https://bloedelreserve.org/), [Bainbridge Gardens](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/https://bainbridgegardens.com/), [Town and Country Market](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/https://townandcountrymarkets.com/markets/bainbridge), [Blakely Harbor Park](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/https://www.bainbridgeisland.com/place/blakely-harbor-park/),[ Suyematsu Farm](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/https://suyematsufarms.com/) and the traditional Japanese garden [Haiku No Niwa](http://web.archive.org/web/20230921084443/http://www.bainbridgepubliclibrary.org/h...

## Land Acknowledgement

The Bainbridge Island Historical Museum is within the ancestral territory of the suq̀ʷabš, “People of Clear Salt Water” (Suquamish People). Expert fishermen, canoe builders, and basket weavers, Suquamish people live in harmony with the lands and waterways along Washington’s Central Salish Sea as they have for thousands of years.
